questions.text: What does the below-depicted image signify?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix of big toe or thumb.

It is characterized by the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. Also, it is associated with nail dystrophy.

Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is important to note that Hutchinson's nail sign is not seen with subungual hematoma.

Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging.

Lentigo Maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve. CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post-gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

 

*Note - Tram track sign refers to the appearance of parallel line lesions and is seen in the following conditions:

  • Tram track sign in the brain is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome
  • Tram track sign in the orbit is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma
  • Tram track sign on microscopy in nephrology is suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Tram track sign in pulmonology is seen in bronchiectasis

questions.text: A nursing mother complains that she’s unable to express breast milk adequately. Her child, a 7 month old boy has a weight for height less than 2 standard deviations below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.

Nutritional status is often assessed in terms of anthropometry:

  • Conversely, a high weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • A low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition.
  • A Low weight for the age indicates acute on chronic malnutrition.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: You are a healthcare worker in an area struck by a sudden onset disaster . Which of the following is not a part of immediate measures taken after a disaster?
questions.solution:
Vector control is done  during the rehabilitation or recovery phase and not immediately after a disaster.

Disaster Management includes three aspects:

1. Disaster impact and response: 

  Involves immediate management of mass casualties

  • Search, rescue, and first-aid
  • Field care
  • Triage
  • Tagging
  • Identification of dead

2. Rehabilitation or recovery:

   Involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions

  • Water supply
  • Basic sanitation and personal hygiene
  • Food safety
  • Vector control

3. Mitigation: Measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing disaster or to reduce the effects of the disaster. This also includes preparedness for any impending disasters or in disaster-prone areas.

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury, there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound. The injury is:
questions.solution:
Based on the ballistics, the gunshot injury is close shot entry wound.

  • The main objective of study of a firearm wound (Ballistics) is to establish the range and direction of firing, the ultimate purpose is to determine the weapon used for firing.
  • Firearm wounds are fundamentally of two mains types: wounds of entry and wound of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.
  • To determine the Range of firing, following parameters are used:
    • Entry wound size and shape
    • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
    • Blackening, Tattooing, Singeing of hair, Abrasion collar and Grease collar
  • In the above options, Hair should be preserved in order to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonisation/dessication in close range, also from lead deposition around the wound to assess range of firing.
Characteristics Contact shot Close Shot Near Shot Distant Shot
Range  In-touch with skin 2.5-7.5 cm 30-60 cm >60 cm
Size Largest size Bullet size Smaller Smallest
Shape Stellate Circular Circular Circular
Blast effect
Muzzle end imprint +ve -ve -ve -ve
Edge eversion +ve -ve -ve -ve
Other findings
Blackening -ve +ve -ve -ve
Tattooing -ve +ve +ve -ve
Singeing -ve +ve -ve -ve
Abrasion collar -ve +ve +ve +ve
Grease collar -ve +ve +ve +ve

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the obstetric criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?

choices.text: ≥ 1 unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus ≥10 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <37 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <34 weeks

questions.solution:
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks(not <37 weeks) is an obstetric criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before 10 weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical
    • Obstetric criteria - 
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular - One or more episodes of arterial or venous or small vessel thrombosis in any organ or tissue
  • Laboratory criteria(2 positive tests at least 12 weeks apart) - 
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Specific therapy in pregnancy: Aspirin plus heparin therapy is the most effective regimen. Women are treated with low-dose aspirin and heparin  for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe. Corticosteroids are used only in secondary APLA syndrome (associated with SLE) and not in primary APLA syndrome. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Women with prior thromboembolic events - prophylactic anticoagulation throughout pregnancy and 6 weeks postpartum with either heparin are recommended. Serial sonographic assessment of fetal growth and antepartum testing should be done in the third trimester due to the risk of fetal growth abnormalities and stillbirths.
  • For women without prior thromboembolic events, acceptable regimes include - 
    • Close antepartum maternal observation with or without prophylactic heparin along with postpartum anticoagulation for 4 to 6 weeks, or
    • Surveillance alone, or
    • Prophylactic heparin + low dose aspirin (if a prior history of recurrent abortion or stillbirth)

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) colour changes shown?
questions.solution:
The vaccine vials that can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) colour changes shown are vials 1 and 2.

From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles. Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same colour (if not, the inner square is a little darker than the outer circle) and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square.

The image below demonstrates the VVM colour changes and use.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions are positive for Clostridium perfringens
questions.solution:
Target hemolysis and reverse CAMP test are positive for Clostridium perfringens.

A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to theta toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to alpha toxin results in target hemolysis on blood agar.

In reverse CAMP test, C.perfringens is streaked over the centre of the plate, Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. Alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produce synergistic hemolysis.

 

M'fadyean reaction is positive Bacillus anthracis.

The CAMP test is positive for Streptococcus agalactiae where it is inoculated on a plate streaked with Staphylococcus aureus.

Elek's test is positive for Corynebacterium diptheriae.

questions.text: Bupivacaine is used in epidural anesthesia for surgical anesthesia is at a concentration of
questions.solution:
The concentration of bupivacaine in epidural anesthesia for surgical anesthesia is at a concentration of 0.5%.

The dosage of local anesthetic in epidural anesthesia depends on the desired clinical effect. It can be used as:

  • Primary anesthetic for surgical anesthesia (sensory + motor block)
  • Combined with general anesthesia to supplement analgesia (sensory block)
  • Postoperative analgesia or labor analgesia (sensory block)
Various concentrations of Bupivacaine and its uses
Concentration Sensory block Motor block Clinical use
0.0625- 0.1% Analgesic None Labor analgesia (walking epidural)
0.1-0.25% Analgesic Minimal Postoperative analgesia
0.5-0.75% Dense Moderate to dense Surgical anesthesia

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion.

questions.text: Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur.

Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which area of trabecular bone is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue. If this occurs in the weight-bearing bones like the femur, it will lead to the bending of bones called as ‘Shepherd’s crook' deformity.

Image: Bending of upper femur in fibrous dysplasia known as Shepherd’s crook deformity

Related Pearl: Classical radiological appearance of bone tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance/

codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma but can be seen in any Malignant lesion

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma but can be seen in any Malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis 

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor,adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance/shepherds

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors(chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn,punctate or comma shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Chicken wire pattern of calcification 

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors(osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment or trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double density fluid levels  and intralesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign or corduroy or jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangiona

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of layers of epidermis from deep to superficial?

choices.text: Stratum basale, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum basale, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum corneum
Stratum corneum, Stratum spinosum, Stratum granulosum,  Stratum basale
Stratum corneum, Stratum granulosum, Stratum spinosum,  Stratum basale

questions.solution:
• The epidermis is the superficial keratinized, stratified, squamous epithelial layer of skin.
  • Skin having only four layers of epidermis is referred to as ‘thin skin’. Most of the skin can be classified as thin skin.
  • From deep to superficial, these layers are the stratum basale, stratum spinosum, stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
  • ‘Thick skin’ is only found in the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. It has an additional fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, located between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of severe combined immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency in SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
  • Deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP), which are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes.
  • In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

X-linked SCID.

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.  
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.     

Other options:

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type II. Orotic aciduria occurs due to the redirection of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Option B: Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy, and hepatic fibrosis.

Option D: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme deficiency leads to a disease called Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the casualty after having overdosed on anti-hypertensive medication. On examination, there are multiple cuts on her wrists and history reveals multiple attempts at suicide. On further enquiry, her father reveals she has marked fluctuations in her mood with a history of unstable relationships. Most probable diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
The given history of repetitive self-destructive acts, unstable relationships and mood swings point towards a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder:  

  • Classified under Cluster B 
  • Characterized by an unstable affect, mood swings, marked impulsivity, unstable relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior, chronic feelings of emptiness or boredom, identity disturbance, and inappropriate anger.
  • If stressed, may become psychotic.
  • The main defense mechanism is splitting.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A patient presented after a road traffic accident (RTA) with fracture of the pelvis. There was urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus with a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination. The probable diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is the rupture of the membranous urethra.

 

  Rupture of the membranous  urethra Rupture of the bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign).
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Urinary retention
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram  Retrograde urethrogram

 

In both cases, the initial management should be the insertion of a suprapubic catheter. Passing a catheter blindly per urethra is not advised as this can convert a partial tear into a complete tear. 

However, delayed urethroplasty is the definitive management for complete urethral tear.

questions.text: Normal astigmatism seen in eyes due to the pressure of the eyelids is _______
questions.solution:
• With the rule, astigmatism is normally seen in the eyes.
  • The vertical meridian is rendered more curved due to the pressure of the eyelids.

Few definitions: 

Against-the-rule astigmatism (ATR): The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians although they are at right angles to each other.

Bi-oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other, at 100 degrees.

      Vertical meridian Horizontal meridian Meridian at right angles to each other

The two principal meridia are

vertical and horizontal

 Yes With the rule More curved
(seen in normal eyes)		   Yes
Against the rule   More curved Yes
No Oblique     Yes
Bi-oblique     No

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male sustains thoracic spinal cord injury in a road accident and develops neurogenic shock. 
In this patient with neurogenic shock, hypotension will be associated with-
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Features of Neurogenic shock:

  • Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic outflow. 
  • Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in decreased peripheral resistance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output, resulting in shock.
  Hypovolemic Cardiogenic Obstructive Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low High
Vascular resistance High High High Low
Venous pressure Low High High Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High
Base deficit High High High High
Type of distributive shock Cause of vasodilation 
Septic shock Bacterial endotoxin and immune activation
Anaphylactic shock Histamine release
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury) Failure of sympathetic outflow

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Decreased blood pressure associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge).
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral fracture

questions.text: Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis shows all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis does not show Birbeck bodies. These bodies are seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions in the giant cells

Noncaseating granulomas can also be seen in:

  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Foreign body granuloma

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

questions.text: While testing the deleterious health hazards on a group of people after giving a new drug and a placebo, the following results were obtained as tabulated. Based on these results, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.1
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 0.9
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10
Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10% and relative risk reduction (RRR) is 9

questions.solution:
• Lets reconstruct the design table in the following way:
  Health hazard (+) Health hazard (-) Total
New drug 1603 (a) 13622 (b) 15225 (a+b)
Placebo 1804 (c) 13421 (d) 15225 (c+d)
  • Relative risk (RR) is given as a/(a+b) ÷c/(c+d).
  • In this scenario, RR = 1603/15225 ÷ 1804/15225 = 0.106/0.118 = 0.89, which is can be rounded up to 0.90. Thus RR = 0.90.
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = 1 – Relative risk. In this scenario, RRR = 1 – 0.9 = 0.1 or 10%.
  • Incidence of a disease is the absolute risk of contracting it.
  • Absolute risk rate of group using new drug = 1603/15225 = 0.106 or 10.6% = 11%. The absolute risk rate of group using placebo = 1804/15225 = 0.118 or 11.8% = 12%.
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo and the drug.
  • In this scenario, ARR = 12% - 11% = 1%.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the root values of reflexes?
questions.solution:
The root value for the cremasteric reflex is L1, L2.

Related Pearl: Root values of the Reflexes

 Reflex  Nerve  Root Value
Biceps Musculocutaneous C5 C6
Brachioradialis Radial C5 C6
Triceps Radial C7 C8
Finger Median and Ulnar C8
Adductor Obturator L2 L3
Knee Femoral L3 L4
Ankle Tibial branch of Sciatic S1 S2
Plantar  Tibial  L5- S2
Abdominal

Upper quadrants- Intercostal nerves 

Lower Quadrants- Intercostal, iliohypogastric & ilioinguinal

Upper Quadrants-T7- T10 

Lower Quadrants-T10- Upper Lumbar segments
Cremasteric Ilioinguinal and Genitofemoral L1, L2
Anal   S2, S3, S4

questions.text: SI unit for absorbed radiation is:
questions.solution:
• SI unit of absorbed radiation is Gray and the common unit is RAD.
    1 Gray = 100 RAD = 1 J/Kg

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 Roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 Rem = 1 Sievert

questions.text: Which of the following is observed in an infant of a diabetic mother?
questions.solution:
Infants of diabetic mothers are at increased risk of hypomagnesemia.

Elevated HbA1c levels correlate with an increased risk of neonatal complications. These include hypoglycemia, respiratory distress syndrome, hypocalcemia, polycythemia, hyperbilirubinemia, hyperviscosity syndrome, and cardiomyopathy, macrosomia , congenital anomalies and unexplained fetal demise. Long-term complications are childhood obesity, neurophysiological effects, and diabetes.

Hyperplasia of fetal β-islet cells occurs due to maternal hyperglycemia. Excess insulin secretion in the fetus leads to blockage of the action of cortisol which activates type II pneumocytes resulting in respiratory distress syndrome. It also makes the fetal interventricular septum and right ventricular wall thicker causing cardiomyopathy. Excess insulin secretion continues even after delivery causing neonatal hypoglycemia.

Fetal hypoxia leads to increased production and subsequent destruction of red cells causing polycythemia and hyperbilirubinemia. Fetal macrosomia (birth weight of more than 4 kg) causes birth injuries due to prolonged labour and shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a:
questions.solution:
The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

Middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses, an oblique cord and interosseous membrane.

  • Oblique cord extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane is a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord, extending distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

 

The illustration below depicts types of fibrous joints.

The illustration below depicts the types of synovial joints.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male underwent emergency surgery following a road traffic accident. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. Which of the following types of respiratory failure is most likely in his perioperative period?
questions.solution:
Type 3 respiratory failure is most likely in the perioperative period.

Type 3 respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. Because atelectasis occurs so commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure.

After general anesthesia, there is a decrease in functional residual capacity due to a reduction in muscular tone. This leads to airway closure and the collapse of dependent lung units.
Atelectasis can be treated by frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and abdominal pain. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Related Pearl: Types of respiratory failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I

Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

(Low paO2 only)

 Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Lung injury and alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pneumonia
  • Acute severe asthma
  • Other causes: Sepsis, gastric aspiration, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

(Low paO2, High PaCO2)

 Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.
  • Respiratory center: brainstem injury, severe hypothyroidism, sleep apnoea, sedative drug overdose.
  • Chest wall and neuromuscular: Kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis, myasthenia gravis, motor neuron disease, myopathy, fatigue.
  • Lung: COPD, pleural pathology, foreign body obstruction.
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drug  is responsible for blisters, erythema, and discoloration of  hand as shown below.?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin is responsible for Purple glove syndrome as shown in the image. 

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly) (First image shown below)

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options: 

Phenobarbitone can also cause blisters (second image shown below) and bullae. But that is usually associated with chronic poisoning and is not an acute reaction. Levitracetam and Lamotrigene and very safe drugs with good efficacy. 

Better alternative for IV phenytoin:

Instead of Phenytoin, IV Fosphenytoin is preferred in the management of status epilepticus. It is a pro-drug and is rapidly converted to Phenytoin and since it is an ester, it seldom causes such reaction. 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes. The flowchart shown below summarizes the management of status epilepticus. 

There are many drugs resulting in acute named syndromes. These are commonly read under the title 'Drug induced Syndromes'. The table below summarizes few of them.

DRUGS SYNDROMES FEATURES TREATMENT
Anticonvulsants, Sulfonamides, Dapsone,
Allopurinol, Minocycline, Gold, Hydroxychloroquine
(HCQ) Sulfate, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ethambutol and
Pyrazinamide		 DRESS - Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms syndrome
  • Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type II T- Helper cells play a role
  • Fever with diffuse maculo-papular rash. 
  • Systemic involvement (Liver and Kindneys > Lungs and Heart)
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Steroids can be used in acute conditions
  • Chronic/ long-standing DRESS needs treatment with Interferon α
L-tryptophan, Amphetamine, Lithium,
Dextromethorphan, Merperidine, Fluoxetine, Trazodone,
Venlafaxine, Buspirone		 Seratonin syndrome
  • Increased serotonergic activity in central neurologic system, due to serotonergic agents. 
  • Neuromuscular (clonus, myoclonus, tremor,
    hyperreflexia)
  • Autonomic (fever, mydriasis, tachycardia,
    tachypnea)
  • Mental status changes (confusion,agitation)
  • Rarely death
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Hyperthermia should be treated with aggressive external cooling measures such as ice, mist, fans and a cooling blanket.
  • Symptomatic support.
  • Cyproheptadine (5-hydroxytryptamine antagonist) is beneficial.
  • Rigidity needs to be treated with Benzodiazepenes. 
Vancomycin, Ciprofloxacin, Amphotericin B, Rifampicin and Teicoplanin Redman syndrome
  • Mild cases sensation of burning and itching, agitation,
    dizziness, headache, chills, fever and perioral paresthesia.
  • pruritus; erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso;
  • severe cases, angioedema
  • cardiovascular collapse
  • antihistamines - Diphenhydramine hydrochloride intravenously averts reaction. 
  • Pretreatment with hydroxyzine can reduce symptoms. 
Amiodarone Blue-gray syndrome
  • Blue-gray skin pigmentation, dyspnea, cough and fever
  • Withdraw the drug.
Dapsone Severe Dapsone Hypersensitivity syndrome
  • High fever lasting for about 4-5 days.
  • malaise, sore throat, dysphagia, productive cough, and pruritic rash
  • methamoglobinemia
  • Corticosteroids orally or topically in mild cases with anti-histamines. 
Butyrophenones, Phenothiazines,
Thioxanthenes, Hydroxyzine, Reserpine;, Amitriptyline,
Amoxapine, Desipramine, Maprotiline, Phenelzine,
Tranylcypromine, Diazepam, Lorazepam, Carbamazepine,
Phenytoin, Amantadine, Bromocriptine, Levodopa, Lithium		 Neurleptic Malignant syndrome
  • Dopaminergic blockade
  • cardinal features
    including autonomic dysfunction
  • altered mental status
  • muscular rigidity, hyperthermia, cogwheel rigidity, dyskinesia, dysphagia, festinating gait, lead pipe muscle rigidity
  • oculogyric crisis 
  • opisthotonos
  • Withdraw the drug
  • Treat hyperthermia by cooling measures.
  • Bromocriptine and Dantrolene sodium.
Penicillin Nicolau Syndrome (Livedoid Dermatitis)
  • Pain around the injection site soon after injection, followed by erythema, livedoid patch, haemorrhagic patch, finally resulting into the necrosis of skin, subcutaneous fat, and muscle. 
  • Stop the drug.
  • Wound care includes antibiotics, dressings and flap reconstructions.
  • Use of Vasoactive agents
    (Pentoxyphylline) together with hyperbaric oxygen may be beneficial considering the vascular pathogenesis.
Warfarin Warfarin induced skin necrosis
  • local paresthesias with an erythematous flush followed by intense pain and rapid development of petechiae. 
  • Vitamin K
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma 
  • Wound care.
Abacavir, All-Trans Retinoic Acid,
Bortezomib, Carbamazapine, Celecoxib, Clozapine,
Diclofenac, Diazepam, Furosemide, Hydralazine, Imatinib,
Lenalidomide, Minocycline, Nitrofurantoin, Norfloxacin,
Ofloxacin, Pegfilgastrin, Propylthiouracil, Quinupristin, Dalfopristin, Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole		 Sweet syndrome
  • relapsing polychondritis, drug-induced lupus, and development of Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies (ANCA).
  • fever, leukocytosis, painful
    erythematous and edematous papules, plaques and nodules
    are seen to be infiltrated by neutrophils. 
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Corticosteroids orally or topically in mild cases with anti-histamines.
Ibuprofen, Allopurinol, Chloroquine,
Penicillamine, Sulfasalazine, Carbamazepine, Etosuximide,
Phenobarbital, Phenytoin, Valpoic Acid, Amoxicillin,
Imipenem, Ciprofloxacin, Clindamycin, Doxycyclin,
Erythromycin, Sulfadiazine, Sulfamethoxazole, Trimethoprim, Dapsone, Fluconazole, Nystatin, Nevirapine,
Abacavir, Efavirenz, Tamoxifen, Verapamil, Enalapril, Acetazolamide.		 Steven - Johnson syndrome
  • Erythema with bullous, eroded lesions of skin
  • cholestatic liver disease. 
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Electrolyte and fluid imbalance to be corrected.
  • Corticosteroids orally
Sulfonamides, Pyrazolones, Barbiturates,
Ibuprofen, Allopurinol and Carbamazepine.		 Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell Syndrome)
  • It comes under spectrum of autoimmune blistering disease, including linear IgA
    dermatosis and paraneoplastic pemphigus.
  • nail dystrophies, ocular complications, trichiasis, symblepharon, distichiasis, visual loss, entropion, ankyloblepharon, lagophthalmos and corneal ulceration.
  • Hyper/ Hypo pigmentation of skin. 
  • withdrawal of the
    causative drug
  • systemic steroids
  • Cyclophosphamide seems helpful.
All anti-psychotics carry the risk  Rabbit syndrome
  • characterized by involuntary, rhythmic, fast and fine
    movements of the oral and masticatory muscles along the vertical axis of the mouth.
  • Accompanied by popping sound
  • Does not involve the tongue.
  • Anticholinergic agents such as Benztropine, Biperiden, Procyclidine and Trihexyphenidyl
Anticonvulsants, Sulfonamides, Penicillins,
Allopurinol, Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs		 Vanishing Bile Duct Syndrome (VBDS)
  • progressive cholestasis
  • Drugs act as a hapten and produce autoantibodies
    against cytokeratin which is in the bile duct, skin,
    conjunctival epithelium and orogenital mucosa.
  • pruritis, weight loss, malaise,
    disappearance of intrahepatic bile duct
  • Withdraw the drug
  • Symptomatic management
  • Use of choleretics
  • Corticosteroids

Chemotherapeutic drugs:

5-Fluorouracil, Doxorubicin, Docetaxel,
Idarubicin, and Cytarabine

 Hand-Foot syndrome
  • Palmar-Plantar
    Erythrodysaesthesia
  • Erythema, tenderness, tingling, numbness, dry
    rash and desquamation over the palms and soles.
  • discontinuation of the causative drug and
    symptomatic care.
  • Steroids and pyridoxine 

Phenytoin

 Purple glove syndrome
  • Intravenous administration of phenytoin resulting
    in soft tissue injury at the site of injection leading to oedema and purplish-black discoloration of the hand.
  • limb elevation
  • physiotherapy
  • low concentration local anaesthetic for brachial plexus block. 

Lithium and Levodopa

 Creutzfeldt-Jakob like Syndrome (CJS)
  • Dementia, confusional state, myoclonus, Parkinson's syndrome, dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria,
    oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm, swallowing difficulties, torticollis and trismus.
  • Withdraw the drug.

Biologics like TNF-Α antagonist, adalimumab, infliximab,
etanercept, α-Interferon and other cytokines. 

 Psuedolymphoma syndrome
  • Fever, cutaneous eruption, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Folic acid is promising. 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: Level 6 lymph node station in the neck refers to ________
questions.solution:
• Level six lymph nodes are the anterior group of lymph nodes. This group includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal nodes.

 

Levels of lymph nodes

Level

Lymph node

1a

Submental

1b

Submandibular

2

Upper jugular

3

Middle jugular

4

Lower jugular

5

Posterior triangle

6

Anterior group

7

Mediastinal

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains of intolerance to loud sounds and mild giddiness associated with ringing in the ear. The intolerance to loud sounds in this patient is due to:
questions.solution:
Intolerance to loud sounds is a feature of all cochlear pathologies. It is due to the recruitment phenomenon (sound is amplified in order to be heard better).

The characteristic presentation of a middle-aged man with vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds points to a diagnosis of Meniere's disease. It is a cochlear pathology, hence shows the recruitment phenomenon.

Rollover phenomenon is a feature of retro-cochlear pathologies like an acoustic neuroma.

Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of a different pitch in the two ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds precipitate a vertiginous attack

questions.text: An athlete participates in a 100 m dash race. Which of the following energy systems is utilized by the muscles of the athlete's body?
questions.solution:
Phosphagen system is utilised by the muscles of the athlete's body.

The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run. Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

Energy systems:

  • The phosphocreatine-creatine system: The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds.
  • The glycogen–lactic acid system: can provide 1.3 to 1.6 minutes of maximal muscle activity.
  • The aerobic system: The aerobic system is the oxidation of foodstuffs in the mitochondria to provide energy. It can sustain mucle activity for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last).

Phosphocreatine is used intravenously in hospitals in some parts of the world for cardiovascular problems under the name Neoton, and also used by some professional athletes, as it is not a controlled substance.
